The main purpose of this Bill is to fix themaximum sum which may he issued to the public Works Loan Commissioners for the purpose of making loans from the Local Loans Fund up to the date of the passing of a further Bill. It is therefore a recurrent measure, but not necessarily at regular intervals. As a rule the amount is fixed at a figure somewhat exceeding the estimated require-ments for the next 12 months, so as to allow a margin in case of delay before further statutory powers can be obtained.2. The current Act v/as passed in July 1932 andauthorises lending up to a maximum of 18 millions. It is estimated that that limit will be reached before the Autumn, and it is therefore necessary to obtain fresh powers before Parliament rises.5. The limit now proposed is 18 millions. Making areasonable allowance for slum clearance and water supply requirements, advances during the 12 months ending July 1935 are not expected to exceed 12 millions; but it is thought desirable to provide a fairly wide margin over that figure, partly to provide against the exigencies of the parliamentary time-table, and partly because a lower figure might be criticised as checking the possibility of a desirable expansion in borrowings for capital expenditure. There is no fear that the higher figure will militate against proper financial controlo4. I should add that a further Bill will have to hepassed before 31st March, 1936, when the present Commissioners' tenure of office will expire.5. I ask for approval of the present Bill in principle,and for authority to introduce it without delay, subject to examination by the Home Affairs Committee.(Intd.)
